qas.question: In the latter part of the 19th century what country took control of Mali?
What year did Mali gain independence as the Mali Federation?
Along with a new constitution, Mali became what type of state in 1991?

answers.text: Mali as a democratic, multi-party state

qas.question: Mali was once part of how many West African empires?
What was the name of the Empire that the country is now named after?

answers.text: Mali Empire (for which Mali is named)

qas.question: What empire is present day Mali part of?
What country took control of Mali in the 1900s?
What was at its peak in the thirteenth century?

context: Present-day Mali was once part of <a3_0>three<a3_0/> West African empires that controlled trans-Saharan trade: the Ghana Empire, <b5_0>the <a4_0>Mali Empire<b5_0/> (for which Mali is named)<a4_0/>, and the Songhai Empire. During its golden age, there was a flourishing of mathematics, astronomy, literature, and art. At its peak in 1300, <b7_0>the Mali Empire<b7_0/> covered an area about twice the size of modern-day <b6_0>France<b6_0/> and stretched to the west coast of Africa. In the late 19th century, during the Scramble for Africa, <a0_0>France seized control of Mali<a0_0/>, making it a part of French Sudan. <b8_0>French Sudan<b8_0/> (then known as the Sudanese Republic) joined with Senegal in 1959, achieving independence in <a1_0>1960<a1_0/> as <b9_0>the Mali Federation<b9_0/>. Shortly thereafter, following Senegal's withdrawal from the federation, the Sudanese Republic declared itself the independent Republic of Mali. After a long period of one-party rule, a coup in 1991 led to the writing of a new constitution and the establishment of <a2_0>Mali as a democratic, multi-party state<a2_0/>.
